awd_titl_txt: Towards the quantum noise limit in semiconductor microwave amplifiers: a study of hot electron noise
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical:

Semiconductor microwave amplifiers are widely used in science and technology. They are widely used, ranging from fundamental science such as the detection of dark matter to applications such as the identification of hazardous chemicals. As they operate at the beginning of the detection circuit, amplifiers are often the main factor limiting the sensitivity of these technologies. The PI will investigate the sources of quantum noise in microwave amplifiers by experiment and theory. Predictions of how noise can be decreased will be experimentally tested through design and characterization of custom devices. The aim of this work is a transformative advance towards reducing noise in microwave amplifiers to the ultimate limit.

Technical:

This project will investigate the precise microscopic origins of electronic noise in high electron mobility transistors using advances in numerical tools and characterization of custom devices. Electron noise in semiconductor devices, arising from fluctuations due to scattering and other mechanisms, must be mitigated for semiconductor amplifiers to approach the quantum noise limit but the microscopic details at the level of individual electronic and vibrational states have been inaccessible. Investigators will employ theoretical and numerical descriptions of carrier transport at such scales to quantitatively identify the contributions of diverse transport processes to noise and how they may be mitigated. Predictions of how noise can be decreased by modifications of device architecture obtained from such studies will be directly experimentally tested using characterization of custom devices. This project will also train students in the microwave electronic technology that is presently in high demand for engineering of quantum hardware such as quantum computers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project, "Towards the quantum noise limit in semiconductor microwave amplifiers: a study of hot electron noise," was to identify the microscopic origin of microwave noise in semiconductor devices in terms of the dynamics of charge carriers, known as electrons and holes. We accomplished this goal using two approaches based on simulation and experiment. Our work ultimately advanced the fundamental understanding of transport and noise in semiconductor materials and devices, knowledge which is of high importance to creating semiconductor devices with improved performance for applications in 5G/6G communications, sensing, astronomy, and quantum computing.

Intellectual Merit: First, we developed a new simulation approach to compute electronic properties of semiconductors which had not been done before. Most simulation programs for charge transport in semiconductors consider the regime where the charge carriers are close to equilibrium. Our approach enabled the calculation of the properties of charge carriers far from equilibrium, in a regime which is applicable to those encountered in real devices. This simulation program required as inputs only the atom identities and locations, making it a parameter-free program to compute charge transport properties. We applied this program to compute the charge transport properties of charge carriers in the valence band (holes) in Si. We were able to resolve several outstanding discrepancies in the literature regarding charge transport in Si because of the capabilities of our simulation approach. This work advanced the fundamental understanding of semiconductors which are critical to modern communication, computing, and sensing technologies.

Second, we investigated the sources of noise in actual devices which arise from characteristics of the device structure and the transport properties of the materials. Specifically, we studied a type of transistor known as a heterojunction bipolar transistor (HBT) made of SiGe alloy and Si. This transistor is of high interest for applications such as self-driving cars, quantum computing, and astronomy. However, its noise performance is not good enough for many applications. We investigated the origin of noise in this device using a specialized probe station that could access temperatures as low as 20 K. We measured how the current and capacitance of a junction in the device varied with the voltage applied to the junction. We found that these measurements indicated the presence of a “leaky,” non-uniform junction arising from defects in the junction. This finding suggests that transistors with carefully grown junctions designed to minimize these imperfections could give better noise performance and thereby advance applications.

Broader Impacts: This project trained two graduate students in semiconductor physics, microwave engineering, experimental and numerical methods, and oral and written scientific communication. The students had the opportunity to attend scientific conferences and present their results. The research outcomes for this project suggest a path forward to realize low noise HBTs in a scalable and low-cost platform compared to the present state-of-art low-noise transistors based on compound semiconductors like InP. Ultimately, HBTs with improved noise performance could have a transformative impact on fields like communication, quantum computing, and radio astronomy.
